contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=January 2007}} {{Infobox Prime Minister | name = Petar Živković | image = Petar Zivkovic.jpg | office = 11th [[Prime Minister of Yugoslavia]] | term_start = 7 January 1929 | term_end = 4 April 1932 | monarch = [[Alexander I of Yugoslavia|Alexander I]] | predecessor = [[Anton Korošec]] | successor = [[Vojislav Marinković]] | office2 = [[Minister without Portfolio]] | term_start2 = 1943 | term_end2 = 1943/45 | monarch2 = [[Petar II of Yugoslavia|Petar II]] | predecessor2 = ''None'' | successor2 = ''None'' | birth_date = 1 January 1879 | birth_place = [[Negotin]], [[Principality of Serbia|Serbia]] | nationality = [[Yugoslavs|Yugoslav]] | religion = [[Serbian Orthodox]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1947|2|3|1879|1|1}} | death_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | party = [[Yugoslav Radical Peasants' Democracy]]<br />[[Yugoslav National Party]] | allegiance = [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] | branch = [[Royal Yugoslav Army]] | serviceyears = 1903-1943 | rank = [[General of the Army]] | battles = [[World War I]] | awards = |}} '''Petar Živković''' ([[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic script]]: Петар Живковић; 1 January 1879 – 3 February 1947) was a [[Serbia]]n soldier and political figure in [[Yugoslavia]]. He was [[Prime Minister]] of the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] from January 7, 1929 until April 4, 1932. ==Life== Petar Živković was born in [[Negotin]], [[Principality of Serbia]] (present-day [[Bor District]], [[Serbia]]) in 1879. A soldier at the Serbian court, he helped to [[May Overthrow|overthrow]] the [[House of Obrenović]], with the assassination of [[Aleksandar Obrenović|King Aleksandar Obrenović]]. He later became a member of the [[Bela Ruka|White Hand]], which opposed the Serbian nationalism of the [[Black Hand (Serbia)|Black Hand]]. In 1921, [[Alexander I of Yugoslavia]] appointed Živković commander of the Palace Guards; in 1929 he was appointed prime minister. Živković held the office as a member of the [[Yugoslav Radical Peasants' Democracy]], or JRSD, which was soon the only legal party in Yugoslavia, due to his electoral "reforms." He resigned as prime minister in 1932, and shortly thereafter founded the [[Yugoslav National Party]], becoming its president in 1936. Meanwhile, Alexander I had been assassinated, in 1934; his cousin [[Prince Paul of Yugoslavia|Pavle Karađorđević]] took office as regent for the 11-year-old [[Peter II of Yugoslavia|Petar II]]. Upon Pavle's 1941 signing of the [[Tripartite Pact]], Živković left Yugoslavia, ahead of the [[Nazism|Nazi]] invasion (see [[Balkans Campaign (World War II)|Balkans Campaign]]). He became part of the Yugoslav government in exile. In 1946 he was tried in absentia in Yugoslavia and sentenced to death. He remained in exile in France, dying in [[Paris]] in 1947, aged 68. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *"[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9078411 Zivkovic, Petar]."
